author: El Tiempo / GDA
title: Joven diagnosticada con cáncer de colon a los 20 años reveló los síntomas que ignoró
text:
20 de febrero de 2025 - 5:52 PM
Dominique McShain, una estudiante universitaria de Nueva Zelanda, compartió su experiencia con el cáncer de colon en un video publicado en TikTok. Aunque llevaba una vida activa y saludable, comenzó a notar signos de alarma que en un principio no relacionó con una enfermedad grave.
Durante su segundo año en la Universidad de Canterbury, tras regresar de un viaje por Asia y mientras se preparaba para cumplir 21 años, sintió un agotamiento extremo que afectó su rutina diaria. A pesar de dormir toda la noche, se veía obligada a tomar siestas durante el día y le costaba asistir a clases.
En mayo de 2024, reveló públicamente su diagnóstico de cáncer colorrectal en etapa avanzada. “Quería empezar este TikTok porque, básicamente, lo que quería hacer en mi vida era ayudar a la gente”, comentó en el video.
Sus planes de seguir la carrera de psicología clínica quedaron interrumpidos, pues los médicos le dieron una expectativa de vida de entre uno y cinco años.
La quimioterapia afectó su capacidad para continuar con sus estudios, por lo que tuvo que dejarlos de lado. “He recibido quimioterapia hasta ahora y he tenido días muy malos”, expresó sobre el tratamiento. A pesar del impacto de la enfermedad, mantiene el objetivo de generar conciencia sobre el cáncer colorrectal y compartir información sobre los síntomas para que otros puedan detectarlo a tiempo.
“Quería marcar la diferencia de algún modo, dejar algo atrás y, con suerte, ayudar a la gente”, mencionó. Además, destacó que “sé que el cáncer de colon es cada vez más frecuente entre los jóvenes”.
Investigaciones recientes han señalado un aumento en los casos de cáncer de colon en personas menores de 55 años. Un informe de 2023 de la Sociedad Americana del Cáncer indicó que el 20 por ciento de los diagnósticos de esta enfermedad en 2019 correspondían a ese grupo de edad, lo que representa el doble de la proporción registrada en 1995.
En una entrevista con New Zealand Herald, Dominique describió los síntomas que experimentó antes del diagnóstico, incluyendo estreñimiento, diarrea, dolores abdominales, sangre en las heces y falta de apetito. Su testimonio alcanzó más de 5 millones de visualizaciones y provocó miles de comentarios de apoyo, con personas que compartieron experiencias similares.
Dominique, agradecida por el apoyo recibido, continúa compartiendo actualizaciones sobre su tratamiento a través de redes sociales.
El cáncer colorrectal se desarrolla en el colon o el recto, partes fundamentales del sistema digestivo. De acuerdo con Mayo Clinic, sus síntomas más comunes incluyen alteraciones en los hábitos intestinales, presencia de sangre en las heces, dolor persistente en el abdomen y sensación de evacuación incompleta.
Las causas exactas de esta enfermedad no están completamente definidas, pero ciertos factores pueden aumentar el riesgo, como el consumo elevado de grasas y bajo en fibra, el sedentarismo, el tabaquismo y el abuso de alcohol. También existen condiciones genéticas que pueden predisponer a algunas personas.
El diagnóstico se establece a través de estudios como la colonoscopia, que permite identificar pólipos o tumores en el intestino. El tratamiento varía según la etapa en la que se detecte y puede incluir cirugía, quimioterapia o radioterapia. La detección temprana es clave para mejorar las probabilidades de éxito en el tratamiento.

title: Long Island Lawmakers Propose Statewide Mask Ban
text:
It may soon be illegal to wear a mask anywhere in New York State — not just Nassau County.
State Sens. Jack Martins (R-Mineola) and Steven Rhoads (R-Wantagh) proposed Thursday a law that would essentially expand Nassau’s Mask Transparency Act to be enacted statewide. The GOP-majority Nassau County Legislature voted of 12-0 with all seven Democrats abstaining before Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman signed the bill into law Wednesday . It makes wearing a face mask illegal, and punishable by a fine and possible jail time.
“Let’s be clear, we’re not talking about people wearing masks for medical reasons,” Martins said. “We’re not talking about people wearing masks for cultural and religious reasons. We’re talking about people wearing masks because they want to hide their identity, and the only reason that they would want to hide their identity is that they do not want to be identified when they commit crimes in this state.”
Blakeman emphasized that the Nassau law is aimed at reducing hate crimes —–- specifically antisemitic hate crimes in the wake of the Oct. 7 terrorist attack on Israel —–- committed by people wearing full face masks, and doesn’t seek to target people wearing masks for medical or religious reasons.
Martins and Rhoads again referred to precedent in laws that targeted the Ku Klux Klan from terrorizing African-Americans, Catholics, and other groups. New York State had a law in place for over 100 years that banned face masks, but it was overturned in 2020 during the height of the Covid-19 pandemic. Gov. Kathy Hochul has expressed support for reinstating the ban, although Rhoads said they have not heard from the governor on the bill.
“It’s the same law, by the way, that was used to thwart organizations like the Ku Klux Klan who are committing violent acts of terror against a segment of our society. That’s the law that we’re looking to put back in place,” Rhoads said. “[For] when campuses return to session and we start to see these protests again.”
Rabbi Ronald Csillag, of MiYaD Chabad, joined the senators to express his support for their bill.
“When I was a kid growing up … the only people wearing masks on TV shows were bank robbers and criminals – other than Batman, and he concealed his identity for a different reason,” Csillag said. “Unfortunately, this whole issue came to light because of antisemitism.”
Nassau Deputy Police Commissioner Kevin Smith told reporters that police have already undergone training to enforce the law fairly.
The full bill, officially proposed by Rhoads, can be viewed here.

author: MARTIN PFLIEGER | FOR LNP | LANCASTERONLINE
title: Hempfield school board tells architects to plan for $211M high school renovation | Community News | lancasteronline.com
text: December 5, 2024 30° Close Hempfield High School FILE PHOTO Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Hempfield school board tells architects to plan for $211M high school renovation MARTIN PFLIEGER | FOR LNP | LANCASTERONLINE Dec 5, 2024 1 hr ago Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Hempfield High School FILE PHOTO Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link When: Hempfield school board meeting, Dec. 3. What happened: The board’s preferred option for upgrading the high school is a $211 million replacement of the Franklin wing of the school and a renovation of the Buchanan wing. The board did not vote on the plan, but by signaling its preference among the three construction options, the architect can begin planning. The choice: The option the board favors would fulfill educational needs and cause the least disruption to students and staff during construction, board members said. Quotable: “The $211 million … was $231 million at one point. I thought to myself, ‘I would love to do that. But I don’t see it happening,’” said Vice President Pat Wagner. “I can see it happening now (with the lower cost). We’re going to have to be vigilant in what we do, there’s no question. The days of 1.1% tax increases, those days are done.” What’s next: Michael Kelly of KCBA Architects said he will present refined drawings to the buildings and grounds committee and the public in February. If the board goes ahead with the project, the work could be put out for bidding as early as January 2026. In the meantime, the district is working with its financial adviser, Raymond James, to determine the best way to finance the project. Taxes: The board discussed the district’s ability to pay for a new contract with teachers, increase pay for administrators and support staff, and renovate the high school. Quotable: “Year one and two, I think we can afford this. Years three and four, I think we run out of taxing authority before we solve this problem,” said board member Grant Keener. More: An average annual tax increase of a little more than 2% would be necessary just to pay for the four-year contract the board approved for teachers, Karen Hall, chief finance and operations officer, said. Quotable: “Quite frankly, if we don’t do it, if we delay this longer, it’s going to cost us a lot more,” board member Charles Merris said of the high school project. Other projects: Last month the board asked administration for more information about the cost of upgrades to Centerville Elementary School and the high school stadium so it could determine if the district could afford to undertake those projects at the same time it is doing the high school work. Centerville Elementary: More data is being collected, however, tentative projections show less residential development in the future, which translates to fewer students, said Superintendent Michael Bromirski. As a result, Bromirski recommended that, for now, the district maintains the building instead of doing an expensive renovation. Future options include renovating and expanding the school or closing it, Bromirski said. The stadium: Nothing in the stadium is up to code, John Michel of Fidevia, the district’s construction consultant, said. Repairing the grandstands, fieldhouse, lighting, bathrooms and press boxes could cost as little as $5.7 million and as much as $12.7 million. Resolution: The board unanimously approved a resolution agreeing to adopt a balanced budget for the 2025-26 school while not raising property taxes above the 4.8% limit the state set for Hempfield. The vote does not commit the board to raising taxes. Approval of a budget is still months away. Reorganization: The board reappointed Michael Donato as president and Pat Wagner as vice president. Next meeting: The board will meet for its education and programming and policy, personnel and legal committee meeting at 5 p.m., Dec. 12. author: Clarence Fanto, The Berkshire Eagle
title: After a prolonged dry spell, rain is expected late Sunday in the Berkshires. What will the next week bring?
text:
We need the rain. We’ve had only a few drops so far this month, on the heels of an extremely dry September.
That normally wet month left only 1.5 inches of rain at Pittsfield Municipal Airport, compared to the historical average of 4.5 inches.
The U.S. Drought Monitor shows most of Massachusetts and portions of nearby states as abnormally dry as of this past Tuesday when weekly data is collected and analyzed. That pre-drought category includes Berkshire County. The North Shore up through the New Hampshire coast and a sliver of southwest Maine already fall into a moderate drought zone.
But the three-day holiday weekend isn’t the ideal time for steady rain. On the bright side, look for a dry, mostly sunny, pleasantly mild but very breezy Saturday here in the Berkshires before the clouds roll in late at night.
Early risers may see a few showers on Sunday, but a storm system south of the Berkshires should yield some steady rain by the afternoon and evening. Total rainfall could top an inch, according to AccuWeather.com, before it ends by early Monday.
The forecast for the holiday into mid-week calls for blustery, chilly, unsettled conditions, according to the National Weather Service. Occasional showers are likely.
“Some snowflakes will likely mix in at times across the higher elevations where some spotty coatings of accumulation cannot be ruled out," said government forecaster Brett Rathbun in an online post.
A gradual clearing out and warmup is expected by midweek, continuing into the following weekend.
SPECTACULAR LIGHT SHOW
Early Thursday evening, photos of a spectacular northern lights show popped up online from Williamstown to Great Barrington. The severe geomagnetic storm produced an awesome aurora borealis show of purple, pink and green images all across Massachusetts, the Cape and Islands between 7 and 8:30 p.m.
The light show even reached Texas and California. The remarkable display was caused by a massive coronal mass ejection, a large expulsion of plasma from the sun that occurred earlier this week, according to Boston Globe meteorologist Ken Mahan.
Geomagnetic storms are harmless to humans but may cause disruptions and lasting impacts to satellites, technology and communications, per the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s space weather prediction center.
Back on Earth, the extended weather outlook from the National Weather Service’s Climate Prediction Center for Oct. 19-25 indicates above-average temperatures and near-normal rainfall.
Day by day . . .
Saturday: Sunny, very windy, high around 60. Clouds gather at night, low in the mid-30s.
Sunday: Rain likely in the afternoon and after dark, high 50-55, low 40-45.
Monday: Early morning rain, then mostly cloudy, high near 55, nighttime low near freezing.
Tuesday: Partly sunny, upper 40s; mostly cloudy at night, low around 32.
Wednesday: Partly cloudy, high 45-50, overnight low near 30.
Thursday: Mostly sunny, near 55. Clear at night, mid-30s.
Friday: Some sunshine, 55-60; partly cloudy after dark, mid-30s.
Saturday (Oct. 19): Sunny, mid-60s.
Sources: National Weather Service and http://AccuWeather.com

author: Bhutan's Daily Newspaper
title: Bhutan advances ESG efforts for sustainable bond market and reporting framework | Kuensel Online
text:
Sherab Lhamo
Environmental, social, and governance (ESG) are key focus areas for global investors in Bhutan to drive growth in sustainable investments. By 2022, assets managed with ESG criteria reached around USD 35 trillion, representing 36 percent of all professionally managed assets worldwide.
Bhutan has integrated ESG and sustainable principles into its economic development strategies for over 60 years.
The CEO of the Royal Sec urities Exchange of Bhutan Dorji Phuntsho said the principles of ESG and sustainable development were deeply embedded in Bhutan long before these terms became widely recognised.
ESG is a set of standards used to evaluate an organisation’s environmental and social impact. While often associated with investing, ESG also encompasses how a company engages with its customers, suppliers, employees, and the wider public.
Despite Bhutan’s alignment with ESG principles and sustainable development values, Dorji Phuntsho pointed out the challenges in capitalising on these efforts.
“We are not yet able to fully monetise or connect with the global financial landscape. Today, our financial market remains in its early stages, relying heavily on bank credit and loans from financial institutions for investments,” he said.
Dorji Phuntsho said Bhutan cannot rely on traditional methods to develop sustainable finance, as this process would take time.
“We are instead working together to design a programme that will accelerate the development of a sustainable bond market in Bhutan,” he said.
The programme will focus on identifying projects that require funding and engaging experts, particularly international agencies specialising in Sustainable Development Goals financing, which will include targeted interventions, covering the entire process from bond issuance to post-issuance, which is notably complex.
“This initiative is specifically designed to build in-house capacity for our issuing companies, regulatory bodies, and market intermediaries,” he said. At the same time, it will explore investment opportunities in sustainable sectors, creating openings for impact investors.
“The programme will be time-bound until we have developed this capacity,” Dorji Phuntsho said.
He said that Bhutan is in the process of developing an ESG reporting standard for listed companies. The initiative aims to monetise Bhutan’s commitment to ESG principles and sustainable development.
The chair of Global Research at J.P. Morgan Chase, Joyce Chang highlighted Bhutan’s strengths: the bold sustainability goals enshrined in its constitution, such as carbon neutrality and land protection, its strong cultural identity, openness to collaboration with private investors, and its strong social values.
JPMorgan Chase & Co., is an American multinational finance company headquartered in New York City.
She recommended Bhutan to begin with a specific sustainable development project, partner with concessional lenders and development institutions, target ESG-focused investors, emphasise transparency and reporting, and consider a mix of funding mechanisms.
The founding partner of Systemiq Capital, Irena Spazzapan said Bhutan’s biodiversity was a valuable resource. She suggested bioprospecting, which involves searching and commercialising genetic materials from natural sources, that holds immense potential for new products and services.
Traditional methods of biodiversity monitoring are expensive and inefficient, but bioprospecting can generate significantly more revenue for Bhutan than carbon trading, she added.
Systemiq Capital, is a company that supports climate tech companies from late seed to Series A/B rounds.
“While hydropower is a valuable resource, Bhutan needs to explore ways to maximise its value beyond just selling electricity. Long-term energy storage solutions are needed to complement renewable energy sources like solar and wind,” said Irena Spazzapan.
The founder of GPI Atlantic, Ronald Colman, raised concerns about the global ESG standards, stating that the global ESG standards are having low bars and being susceptible to greenwashing.
He added that despite 80 percent of global investors claiming sustainable portfolios, environmental and social challenges persist. He warned that these weak standards undermine trust in the investment industry.
Ronald Colman praised Bhutan’s “fail-safe immaculate ESG standards,” rooted in the country’s Gross National Happiness (GNH) philosophy. He explained that GNH, based on Bhutanese wisdom traditions, emphasises interdependence with all life—a genuine sustainability standard.
When asked about Bhutan’s potential to fully harness its hydropower and retain economic benefits within the country, Dorji Phuntsho acknowledged the opportunity to add value to this energy source.
He mentioned green hydrogen as a potential option for energy storage and stressed the importance of policies that value addition and better utilisation of Bhutan’s energy resources.
For Bhutan to set up an effective ESG reporting system and establish transparent frameworks, Joyce Chang recommended that Bhutan, if it moves toward a capital market strategy, should create a comprehensive ESG reporting framework aligned with international standards.
This would involve regular ESG data disclosures, developing measurable metrics, and collaborating with international organizations.
